item.title: Mexican Forces Kill ‘El Mencho,’ Nation’s Most-Wanted Cartel Boss
item.description: “El Mencho” was the longtime head of one of the nation’s most powerful cartels. Armed groups set fire to cars and buildings across Mexico in the wake of his death.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Paulina Villegas
item.media:description: Police officers securing an area where vehicles were set on fire by organized crime members in Zapopan, Mexico, on Sunday.

item.title: The Ex-Taxi Driver at the Center of Russia’s Shadow War
item.description: The Kremlin’s sabotage campaign against European allies of Ukraine has been escalating. It needs people like Aleksei Kolosovsky, 42, to carry it out.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Adam Goldman
item.media:description: A 2024 arson attack outside Warsaw was one of several plots carried out in Europe by a criminal network on behalf of Russian intelligence services, according to European officials.

item.title: Iran Students Protest for Second Day Despite State Crackdown
item.description: Student groups reported protests at universities in Iran’s two largest cities as the government grapples with domestic discontent and the threat of U.S. strikes.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Sanam Mahoozi and Devon Lum
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A screen grab from a social media post that was verified by The New York Times showing demonstrators at the Tehran University of Art on Sunday.

item.title: St. Francis’ Remains, Rarely Seen, Go on Display in Assisi
item.description: The bones of Italy’s patron saint will be shown to the public for a month, to mark the 800th anniversary of his death.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Believers lined up to see the bones of St. Francis at the basilica bearing his name in Assisi, Italy, on Sunday.

item.title: Arab Leaders Condemn Remarks by U.S. Ambassador to Israel
item.description: The ambassador, Mike Huckabee, seemed to endorse Israeli control of lands stretching from Egypt to Iraq. He said his comments were taken out of context.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Ambassador Mike Huckabee told Tucker Carlson, the podcaster, that it “would be fine” if Israel “took it all,” referring to much of the Middle East. Arab and Islamic countries denounced his remarks.

item.title: Inside Iran’s Preparations for War and Plans for Survival
item.description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has entrusted Ali Larijani, the top national security official, to ensure the Islamic Republic endures any military attacks and targeted killings.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ali Larijani, the secretary of the Supreme National Security Council of Iran, in May 2024.

item.title: Fat Signing Bonuses, and Concierge Service, for Family Doctors
item.description: In a country where a quarter of the population lacks a family doctor, Canadian communities compete in a zero-sum battle to recruit family doctors.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Gavin John
item.media:credit: Gavin John for The New York Times
item.media:description: The town of Stettler, Alberta’s economy is predominantly driven by the agriculture and oil industries, and is the largest town for surrounding communities.

item.title: Russia Attacks Ukraine Ahead of Invasion’s 4th Anniversary
item.description: At least one man was killed in Kyiv as Moscow launched a wave of drones and missiles, days after the latest round of U.S.-mediated talks to end the war.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers at the site where a policewoman was killed in an explosion in Lviv, Ukraine, on Sunday. It was not clear whether Russia was involved.

item.title: Trump Looks Ahead to Summit With China’s Xi, but Tariffs and Taiwan Loom
item.description: President Trump said his planned meeting with President Xi Jinping would be a grand display, but tensions over trade and defense could dampen the mood.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: The last time President Trump and President Xi Jinping of China met was in October in Busan, South Korea.

item.title: Johannes Hoesflot Klaebo Leads Norway to Record Olympic Medal Haul
item.description: Norway, led by the cross-country skiing sensation Johannes Hoesflot Klaebo, topped the medal table for the fourth straight Winter Games.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Louise Krüger
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patrons watching the closing ceremony of the Winter Olympics at a local sports bar in Tromso, Norway, on Sunday.

item.title: The A.I. Evangelists on a Mission to Shake Up Japan
item.description: Team Mirai, a political party founded by software engineers, won 11 seats in Japan’s legislature by promising chatbots, self-driving buses and high-tech jobs.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:credit: Kentaro Takahashi for The New York Times

item.title: The Queen Stuck by Prince Andrew. King Charles Is Pulling Away
item.description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, the former prince, is getting no help from the throne as the crisis over his ties to Jeffrey Epstein intensifies.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Prince Andrew, as he was then known, escorted his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, to a memorial service for his father, Prince Philip, at Westminster Abbey in London in March 2022.

item.title: Gisèle Pelicot Survived Mass Rape. Now She’s Looking to the Future.
item.description: Gisèle Pelicot stayed silent after dozens of men were convicted of raping her. Now, Ms. Pelicot is finding peace by publicizing her ordeal and explaining how she survived it.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.category: A Hymn to Life: Shame Has to Change Sides (Book)
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times

item.title: Uncertainty in Europe After Trump’s Supreme Court Tariff Loss
item.description: The decision could distract from other challenges facing the continent, like issues with China and the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump criticized the Supreme Court tariff ruling at a news conference in Washington on Friday.

item.title: Duterte’s Fans Rally in The Hague as the I.C.C. Weighs Evidence Against Him
item.description: The protests are a sign of the Philippine ex-leader’s ongoing influence, even as he faces a possible trial for the deaths of thousands during his war on drugs.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Rodrigo Duterte, the former leader of the Philippines, on Saturday outside the International Criminal Court detention center on the outskirts of The Hague.

item.title: Tour Montparnasse is One of Paris’s Uglier Landmarks. It’s Getting a Makeover.
item.description: The Tour Montparnasse is one of Paris’s least-loved landmarks. After half a century, it’s finally being remodeled.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler, Ségolène Le Stradic and Dmitry Kostyukov
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times

item.title: What to Know About the Killing of ‘El Mencho’
item.description: The Mexican government has killed Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes, the longtime leader of one of Mexico’s most powerful gangs, the Jalisco New Generation Cartel.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Firefighters extinguishing a burning bus in Jalisco state, Mexico, on Sunday. Organized crime groups set fire to buildings and vehicles across the country in response to the death of Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes.

item.title: Trump Considers Targeted Strike Against Iran, Followed by Larger Attack
item.description: The top negotiators plan to meet in Geneva on Thursday for last-ditch talks, debating a new proposal that could create an off-ramp as two carrier groups massed within striking distance of Iran.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, David E. Sanger, Tyler Pager and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump’s threat is the latest example of how he is trying to force Iranian leaders to see that they have no choice but to give up every aspect of their nuclear program.

item.title: Courting China Again
item.description: The German chancellor will travel to Beijing this week, the latest high-level visitor as Western countries pivot back to China.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain in Shanghai last month.

item.title: Fans Pack Bars as U.S.-Canada Hockey Game Puts Rivalry on the Line
item.description: Canadians and Americans jammed bars that opened early on Sunday to watch the United States deal the Canadian team, and the country, a devastating blow in overtime.
item.dc:creator: Shawna Richer and Rylee Kirk
item.media:credit: Brendan George Ko for The New York Times
item.media:description: At the Pilot, one of Toronto’s oldest bars, more than 300 people, most wearing red, jammed onto two floors starting at 7:30 in the morning to watch Canada play on big screens.

item.title: Iran Could Direct Proxies to Attack U.S. Targets Abroad, Officials Warn
item.description: Security officials are monitoring increasingly worrisome signs as President Trump considers another military campaign against Iran.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A new billboard in Tehran this month. The uncertainty surrounding possible threats from Iran’s proxy groups further complicates the Trump administration’s war planning.

item.title: Trump Tensions Turn U.S.-Canada Olympic Hockey Final Into a ‘Grudge Match’
item.description: The tensions between the Trump administration and Canada were largely cast aside at the men’s Olympic gold medal game, which the U.S. team won in overtime.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: The U.S. men’s hockey team prepares to take the ice against Canada in the gold medal match in Milan on Sunday.

item.title: Iran’s Students Hold Anti-Regime Protests as Universities Reopen
item.description: Students helped grow initial protests into a national movement crushed by the government. As the new semester began, they chanted and marched again.
item.dc:creator: Leily Nikounazar, Pranav Baskar and Devon Lum
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Demonstrators gathering at Amirkabir University in Tehran, in an image from a social media post that was verified by The New York Times.

item.title: For Dutch speedskater, age doesn’t matter.
item.description: Jorrit Bergsma, a gold medalist back in 2014, is now 40. But he rolled back the years to win gold.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and Doug Mills

item.title: At Least 10 Killed in Lebanon, Officials Say, After Israel Strikes Hezbollah
item.description: The Lebanese militant group said eight of its members were among those killed late Friday. The attacks threaten to further destabilize an already tenuous cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Hwaida Saad
item.media:description: Coffins draped in fabric bearing the symbol of Hezbollah are carried through the village of Nabi Sheet, eastern Lebanon, on Saturday.

item.title: Young Skaters Assist With Figure Skating Competitions While Aspiring to the Olympics
item.description: Young skaters known as flower kids jump into action. They have their own Olympic dreams.
item.dc:creator: Weiyi Cai

item.title: Searching for Rejuvenation Where Skiers Chase Olympic Gold
item.description: The thermal waters of the Italian Alps, long praised for their restorative properties, are well known to elite athletes. During the Winter Games, they’ve drawn spectators, too.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei and Gabriela Bhaskar

item.title: Future Perfect
item.description: Does taking care of our future selves have to mean sacrifice in the present?
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Klaebo Makes Olympic History: Unforgettable Photos from 6-Gold Sweep
item.description: Johannes Klaebo won his sixth cross country gold medal at the 2026 Olympics.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and Vincent Alban

item.title: How Johannes Klaebo’s 6 Gold Medals Ranks Among the All-Time Olympic Performances
item.description: The Norwegian cross-country skier completed the biggest medal haul ever by an athlete at a Winter Games, and one of the biggest at any single Olympics.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:description: Johannes Klaebo of Norway won gold on Saturday in the 50-kilometer mass start individual race.

item.title: Supreme Court Ruling on Trump’s Tariffs Changes Little for Canada
item.description: The president’s tariffs that are inflicting the most harm to Canada’s economy are outside the scope of the Supreme Court case.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: The 50 percent tariffs on Canadian steel that have led to layoffs at Algoma Steel are not affected by the court decision.

item.title: Why Attacking Iran Could Be Riskier Than Capturing Maduro
item.description: Iran’s extensive military abilities and network of regional proxies could draw the United States into a prolonged conflict.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Samuel Granados

item.title: Los Angeles Olympics Have a Cloud of Concerns as Winter Games Close
item.description: New details about the LA28 chairman’s ties to Jeffrey Epstein, as well as anxiety over key infrastructure projects, have thrown the planning into disarray.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez and Heather Knight
item.category: Los Angeles Organizing Committee for the Olympic and Paralympic Games 2028 (LA28)
item.media:description: Los Angeles Olympics organizers addressed the International Olympic Committee in Milan, Italy, this month, to promote the next Summer Games.

item.title: How $600 Drones Are Outsmarting Colombia’s Billion-Dollar Military
item.description: Security officials say easy access by guerrilla groups to commercial drones, cheaply modified into deadly weapons, has put the nation’s army on its heels.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak and Simón Posada
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Robinson Hernandez and John Silva, who work for a company that specializes in drone and anti-drone technology, using devices to neutralize drones during a test in Bogotá, Colombia.

item.title: At A.I. Summit, India Tries to Find a Way Between the U.S. and China
item.description: India is using technology as a tool of foreign policy, casting itself as a moral voice for smaller, developing countries.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das and Pragati K.B.
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: A humanoid robot dancing in front of an audience at a pavilion during the A.I. Impact Summit in New Delhi on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump Official Backs Russia’s Return to Global Sports
item.description: Paolo Zampolli, a special envoy for President Trump, endorsed Russia’s participation at next month’s Paralympics, a move greeted with dismay in European capitals.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: Maurizio Fiorino for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paolo Zampolli in Milan in 2024.

item.title: How Olympic Experts Keep the Ice Intact
item.description: A team of skilled technicians and drivers keep the frozen surface at the right temperature and thickness. The challenge? Each event needs a different kind of ice.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Josephine de La Bruyère
item.media:description: Ice-resurfacing machines known as Zambonis restore the frozen surface of competition before, during and after Winter Olympics competitions.

item.title: Russia Takes the Gulag Out of the Gulag History Museum in Moscow
item.description: The museum had preserved the history of brutality inflicted by the Soviet Union on its people. It will now focus on Nazi war crimes.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: An exhibition at the Gulag History Museum in Moscow in 2022. There are plans to turn the space into a Museum of Memory focused on Nazi war crimes.

item.title: Hungary Poses Unexpected Hurdle to Europe’s 90-Billion Euro Loan to Ukraine
item.description: While the delay may prove to be procedural, Hungary signaled that it could cause problems as the European Union works to send money to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: The Hungarian foreign minister, Peter Szijjarto, in Prague, Czech Republic, last month.

item.title: 3 People Are Killed in Series of Avalanches in Austrian Alps
item.description: The police said several other rescues took place. The avalanches happened amid severe weather warnings across the region.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson, Melina Delkic and Amy Graff

item.title: Ferreira completes his halfpipe set with gold.
item.description: The American Alex Ferreira nailed his final run to win gold in the ski halfpipe.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and Gabriela Bhaskar

item.title: Christopher S. Wren, Times Bureau Chief in Hostile Lands, Dies at 89
item.description: Over three decades, he reported from Moscow, Beijing, Tehran and elsewhere and wrote well-received books based on his reporting, including one about his globe-trotting cat.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:description: Mr. Wren in an undated photo. Explaining why he went into journalism, he said, “I wanted to find a job where I could go out and satisfy my curiosity and have somebody pay for it.”

item.title: Nazi Execution Photos Went Up For Sale. Greece Stopped It.
item.description: The images of political prisoners, taken just before they were killed by Nazis in 1944, were put up for auction on eBay. The sale was pulled shortly thereafter.
item.dc:creator: Koba Ryckewaert and Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: An image of Greek prisoners being led to their execution in 1944 was projected onto a wall at the site of the shootings, in Kaisariani, Greece, on Wednesday.

item.title: After Supreme Court Loss, Trump Plans to Impose Global Tariffs Using Different Laws
item.description: The administration has been preparing for months for the possibility that the Supreme Court would rule against the president and developed contingency plans.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Using different legal authorities, President Trump plans to impose a 10 percent global tariff and open investigations into certain, unspecified countries’ unfair trade practices.

item.title: Palestinian-American Teenager Killed in West Bank Is Laid to Rest
item.description: Nasrallah Abu Siyam, 19, was shot dead by an Israeli settler, according to a witness and Palestinian health officials, amid rising violent settler attacks in the Israeli-occupied territory.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Fatima AbdulKarim
item.media:description: The funeral of Nasrallah Abu Siyam, 19, in Mukhmas, a village in the West Bank, on Thursday, a day after he was killed.

item.title: India’s Hindu Right Seems Unstoppable. This City Shows How.
item.description: Muslims make up a majority in Sambhal, but after deadly clashes over a mosque, they say they the arms of the state are now stifling them.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Suhasini Raj and Saumya Khandelwal
item.media:description: The Shahi Jama Masjid mosque in Sambhal, India, was the site of violent clashes between Muslims and the police in November 2024.

item.title: Venezuela Releases Political Prisoners, With Conditions
item.description: Since Nicolás Maduro’s capture by the United States, Venezuela has released hundreds of political prisoners and approved a new amnesty law, although the restrictions on those freed have raised questions about whether this signals real change. Our international correspondent Simon Romero describes what’s happening.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero, Leila Medina, Melanie Bencosme, June Kim, Patricia Sulbarán, Marian Carrasquero and Isayen Herrera

item.title: Iran Says U.S. Has Not Asked It to Stop Enriching Uranium
item.description: The comments by Iran’s foreign minister on Friday contradicted the Trump administration’s position.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:description: Abbas Araghchi, the foreign minister of Iran, at the United Nations office in Geneva. The United States and Iran have been in Switzerland negotiating a nuclear deal this week.

item.title: Johannes Dale-Skjevdal of Norway Wins Biathlon Mass Start
item.description: Johannes Dale-Skjevdal of Norway hit all 20 of his shots to win the gold medal in the mass start event.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and James Hill
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times

item.title: In Ukraine, Senators See War’s Impact and Press for Stronger U.S. Support
item.description: Senate Democrats traveled to Kyiv and Odessa to show solidarity with the war-torn nation and make the case that the United States should do more, including imposing harsh sanctions on Russia.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.media:description: Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, on a tour of the Darnytsia power plant in Kyiv, Ukraine, which was damaged in a Russian attack this month.

item.title: As Trump Considers Second Iran Attack, It Could Be Deadlier Than the First
item.description: Within days of the U.S. strikes on Iran’s nuclear facilities last year, all sides agreed to a cease-fire. This time could be different.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A missile display at a celebration in Tehran this month.

item.title: A Cancer Detection Test Fails in Major Study
item.description: A closely watched clinical trial in Britain that screened blood for early detection of cancer did not show a reduction in diagnoses at later stages of the disease.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Gina Kolata
item.media:description: The Galleri test looks for tiny shards of cancer DNA in the blood.

item.title: Former Prince Andrew’s Arrest Upends Royal Family’s Effort to Move Past His Scandal
item.description: King Charles III’s family, long rocked by infighting and grievous losses, is facing what could be the gravest threat to its moral authority in more than a generation.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Megan Specia
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, center, the brother of King Charles III, after leaving a police station on Thursday.

item.title: U.K. Police Contacting Security Officers Who Once Protected Former Prince Andrew
item.description: The authorities also searched a mansion used by Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, who was arrested in connection with an investigation into suspicion of misconduct in public office.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: The arrest of Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor has shocked Britain and made headlines around the world.

item.title: Head of Russia’s Antidoping Agency Was Involved in 2014 Doping Scheme, Whistle-Blower Claims
item.description: The accusation surfaced as Russia tries to re-establish its Olympics eligibility.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:description: Veronika Loginova, director general of the Russian antidoping agency.

item.title: How China Is Stoking Fear About Travel to Japan
item.description: From earthquake warnings to bear attack alerts, Beijing is deploying a campaign of exaggeration and disinformation to punish Tokyo’s support for Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Visitors on a street decorated for the Lunar New Year at China Town in Yokohama near Tokyo on Tuesday.

item.title: Olympics Gold Medalist Eclipsed By Her Toddler
item.description: A champion speedskater spoke to reporters with her toddler. The focus on her child was among several instances at the Olympics that highlighted the complexities working mothers face in Italy.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: The Italian speedskater Francesca Lollobrigida won two gold medals and set an Olympic record at the Games in Milan.

item.title: A New U.S. Blockade Is Strangling Cuba
item.description: An analysis of ship movements shows that the Trump administration is isolating the island at one of its most vulnerable moments.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Christiaan Triebert
item.media:description: The oil tanker Ocean Mariner at the port of Havana last month. Cuba is facing the United States’ first effective blockade since the Cuban Missile Crisis.

item.title: A Makeup Ban in Syria for Women in Government and Public Sector Stirs Outrage
item.description: A provincial governor wants to prohibit women in government and public sector jobs from wearing makeup, stirring outrage and many, many memes.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women spending time at a cafe in Latakia, Syria, in May.

item.title: An Enemy’s Fall Frees Up South Korea’s Leader. Now Comes the Tough Part.
item.description: President Lee Jae Myung gained legitimacy from his predecessor’s conviction​. But South Korea’s political polarization is caustic, and could get worse.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Lee Jae Myung at the National Assembly in Seoul, South Korea in 2024.
